Description: CD4<sup>+ </sup>T cells play critical roles in generating cytotoxic CD8<sup>+ </sup>T cells and regulating the tumor-suppressive or tumor-promoting phenotypes of cells in the tumor microenvironment. Despite being central orchestrators of the tumor immune response, our understanding of CD4<sup>+ </sup>T cells in tumors and the ways in which they can be harnessed therapeutically continues to lag our understanding of CD8<sup>+ </sup>T cells. This session is focused on the status of what is known about CD4<sup>+ </sup>T cells in tumors and highlights the exciting avenues being explored for their therapeutic targeting. Topics to be discussed will include emerging evidence of sex-based differences in tumor associated regulatory CD4<sup>+ </sup>T cells; the indirect ways in which CD4<sup>+ </sup>T cells mediate antitumor immunity and cell-based therapies targeting these functions; and the ways in which cytotoxic CD4<sup>+</sup> T cells and their TCRs can be harnessed to mediate direct tumor cell killing.
